abstract: Jerry Yang, the chief executive of Yahoo, has emerged as an unlikely survivor – at least for now, The New York Times says in a look at Mr. Yang’s moves, past and present. He beat back his Microsoft counterpart Steven A. Ballmer, whose offers to buy all or part of Yahoo were considered inadequate by Mr. Yang and his board. And he rebuffed Carl C. Icahn, the activist shareholder, who tried to seize control of Yahoo but settled for three seats on an expanded board.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Yang, the chief executive of Yahoo, has emerged as an unlikely survivor – at least for now, The New York Times says in a look at Mr. Yang’s moves, past and present. He beat back his Microsoft counterpart Steven A. Ballmer, whose offers to buy all or part of Yahoo were considered inadequate by Mr. Yang and his board. And he rebuffed Carl C. Icahn, the activist shareholder, who tried to seize control of Yahoo but settled for three seats on an expanded board.

headline.main: Yahoo Is Still Searching for, Well, Yahoo
